newsitem.title: GREECE: Drachma firms vs Ecu, pushes rates down, bonds up.
newsitem.headline: Drachma firms vs Ecu, pushes rates down, bonds up.

text.p: The drachma regained composure against the ecu on Friday after early ecu sales from domestic players helped the currency, driving short-term deposits lower and boosting fixed-coupon bond prices by half a point.
"Ecu/drachma opened at 312 but fell to 311.45/50 after hitting a low of 311.30 on consistent ecu selling from local banks," said one forex dealer at a foreign bank.
He said that the central bank's intervention at the fixing and its afternoon forex window to support the drachma in the last few days had convinced some players that "the worst is behind us."
The Bank of Greece has sold more than 1.2 billion ecus this week to prop up the drachma.
Bond prices pared loses in early dealings with fixed coupon bonds gaining about 50 basis points in price and FRNs edging up on sharply lower deposit rates.

One and three-month deposits opened at 12-12.50 percent but tumbled to 10.50 percent to 11 percent in thin trading. Six-month depos were quoted 50 basis lower while nine- to 12-month rates were little changed.
Forex forwards in one-year tenors slipped 50 forward points, traders said.
The mark was quoted at 160.00/05 from Thursday's 160.20 fix, the dollar at 272.70/80 drachmas from 272.920 and the ecu at 311.40/50 from 312.000 drachmas.
